instruction: What metric was chosen to estimate aboveground biomass (AGB) in pastures under integrated crop-livestock systems (ICLS), and how well did it perform?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the models in estimating pasture aboveground biomass (AGB) was the coefficient of determination (R2). The tested models achieved R2 values ranging from 0.60 to 0.70, indicating moderate to strong correlations between the predicted AGB values and the actual field measurements. The best-performing model had an R2 value of 0.70, indicating a relatively high level of accuracy in estimating pasture AGB.

instruction: How did the researchers use machine learning models to estimate pasture AGB in the integrated crop-livestock systems (ICLS) using UAV imagery?
Output: The researchers used machine learning models, specifically the random forest (RF) algorithm, to estimate pasture aboveground biomass (AGB) in integrated crop-livestock systems (ICLS) using UAV imagery. They tested several datasets of variables, including original spectral bands (RGB-NIR), vegetation indices, and gray-level cooccurrence matrix (GLCM) textures. The RF algorithm was applied along with feature selection methods to identify the most relevant variables for estimating pasture AGB. The models were trained and tested using field measures of pasture AGB obtained through three field campaigns over five months to capture the spatiotemporal variability of the pasture fields. The models achieved similar results in estimating pasture AGB (R2: 0.60 to 0.70), with the number of variables selected for the RF algorithm varying among models (from 6 to 160 variables). The most accurate models used few variables, with two models relying solely on texture measures and the third model incorporating combined spectral bands and vegetation indices. The best-performing model, with an R2 of 0.70, utilized only 10 texture measures.
